statements.text: In Basil’s London studio, the painter introduced Dorian Gray to Lord Henry Wotton, and the meeting stirred in Basil a mingled pride and dread he scarcely understood.
The portrait Basil created in that studio became his masterpiece, for Dorian’s beauty awakened in him an artistic devotion bordering on spiritual worship.
The shabby theatre where Sibyl Vane performed seemed transformed each night by her genius, drawing both London’s weary crowds and Dorian’s rapt attention.
James Vane warned Sibyl that gentlemen from Mayfair brought ruin more often than romance.
In Basil’s studio, Harry’s glittering paradoxes fell upon Dorian like spells, and the painter feared the influence long before he dared speak of it.
Sibyl’s acting collapsed the night she discovered real love, for the very feelings that redeemed her heart shattered the illusions upon which her art depended.
The portrait hanging in Dorian’s locked attic chamber altered subtly after Sibyl’s suicide, as though the painted face itself had begun to accuse someone in silence.
Basil confided to Harry that he feared the corruption of Dorian’s soul, admitting he had once worshipped the boy too passionately.
James Vane hunted through London’s opium dens for the mysterious gentleman tied to Sibyl’s fall, driven by a vengeance no moral appeal could soften.
The portrait’s face grew cruel and shadowed with each new sin committed, even as the living Dorian walked through Mayfair untouched by time.
Basil confronted the altered portrait in the attic and felt an anguish deeper than fear, for he realized his art had recorded a spiritual corruption he could neither explain nor rectify.
On the night before departing for France, Basil Hallward vanished, leaving behind only the silent studio and a mystery that neither friends nor acquaintances could unravel.
